data.1:
(cid:57) Introduction 
(cid:57) Input-output K balances – different 
approaches, what do they tell?
(cid:57) ‘Nutrient mining’ – how to assess soil K 
weathering rates and potential?
(cid:57) Results from research combining (i) 
simulation modelling, (ii) long-term field 
experiments, (iii) qualitative and quantitative 
characterization of K sources and sinks, and 
(iv) GIS based maps
(cid:57) Conclusions and challenges ahead

table_id: Long-term K dynamics in organic and conventional mixed cropping systems as related to management and soil properties_table_2

data.0:
Introduction - Why research on K?
•
Strong focus on N and P
•
Decrease in K fertiliser application in many 
European countries (see Fig).
•
Negative K balances have been reported at 
farm and field level, especially in grass 
dominated low input systems (e.g. organic 
systems). 
•
Delivery of K from soil mineral sources can be 
of crucial importance for the long-term 
sustainability – how to assess?.
•
There are areas where there will be a need for 
K-supplementation – but where?
Innehåll
•
Project: “K-dynamics in agricultural soils–
quantifying K sinks and sources including 
mineral weathering and identifying soils 
(areas) in need of K-supplementation”
•

This presentation was made at the IPI-OUAT-IPNI International Symposium, 5-7 November 2009, OUAT, Bhubaneswar, Orissa, India. The Role and Benefits of Potassium in Improving Nutrient 
Management for Food Production, Quality and Reduced Environmental Damage.

table_id: Long-term K dynamics in organic and conventional mixed cropping systems as related to management and soil properties_table_31

data.0:
Conclusions 
(cid:57) In a K deficient grass system the total net K off-take 
(30 yrs) was 1100 kg K ha-1 (38 kg ha-1 yr-1) being 
released from non-exchangeable sources.
(cid:57) The Ex-K pool in the rooting zone (0-40 cm) was 
~100 kg ha, i.e. Ex-K is a dynamic pool that has been 
replenished 10 times during the experimental period.
(cid:57) Evaluation of long-term field experiments showed K 
release rates in the range 8-65 kg K ha-1 yr-1
(cid:57) Model simulations estimated a weathering of 3-80 kg 
K ha-1 yr-1 depending on e.g. soil mineralogy, soil 
texture, climate. 
Swedish University of Agricultural Sciences
www.slu.se

This presentation was made at the IPI-OUAT-IPNI International Symposium, 5-7 November 2009, OUAT, Bhubaneswar, Orissa, India. The Role and Benefits of Potassium in Improving Nutrient 
Management for Food Production, Quality and Reduced Environmental Damage.
